unnormalised: Someone asked me how safe are online transactions these days in India? Well, it's a mixed bag. On one hand, platforms like Amazon and Flipkart have pretty secure payment gateways using protocols like SSL, with 128-bit encryption. They also offer buyer protection, refund policies, and escrow services to minimize risk. Most debit cards issued by banks like SBI and HDFC require 2-factor authentication (2FA) with OTPs, which adds an extra layer of security. You can see a "padlock" icon in your browser's address bar that confirms it's a secured website, using https.
normalised: Someone asked me how safe are online transactions these days in India? Well, it's a mixed bag. On one hand, platforms like Amazon and Flipkart have pretty secure payment gateways using protocols like S-S-L, with one hundred and twenty eight bit encryption. They also offer buyer protection, refund policies, and escrow services to minimize risk. Most debit cards issued by banks like S-B-I and H-D-F-C require two-factor authentication (two-F-A) with O-T-P-s, which adds an extra layer of security. You can see a "padlock" icon in your browser's address bar that confirms it's a secured website, using H-T-T-P-S.

unnormalised: However, phishing scams are still rampant. Cybercriminals send fake emails or SMSes that look legitimate, tricking users into entering their credit card details or bank account numbers on fake websites. Never click on links in suspicious emails and always verify the URL. In 2023, the Indian Computer Emergency Response Team (CERT-In) reported over 1.3 million cyber security incidents, many of which were related to online financial fraud. A lot of times, the fraudulent transactions may be for a relatively smaller amount, say ₹ 500, to test if the user is vigilant.

unnormalised: UPI (Unified Payments Interface) is convenient, but also has its risks. Many people fall prey to scams where they are asked to "receive" money by entering their UPI PIN. Remember, a UPI PIN is only required when you are sending money, not receiving it. Scammers also use QR codes to direct users to malicious websites or apps. Always double-check the recipient's name and UPI ID before making a payment. For instance, my neighbour Sharma Ji lost ₹ 20000 in such a scam last year.
normalised: U-P-I (Unified Payments Interface) is convenient, but also has its risks. Many people fall prey to scams where they are asked to "receive" money by entering their U-P-I P-I-N. Remember, a U-P-I P-I-N is only required when you are sending money, not receiving it. Scammers also use Q-R codes to direct users to malicious websites or apps. Always double-check the recipient's name and U-P-I I-D before making a payment. For instance, my neighbor Sharma Ji lost rupee twenty thousand in such a scam last year.

unnormalised: Then there are issues with data breaches. If a website or app you use is compromised, your payment information may be stolen. Companies are required to comply with data protection laws like the Information Technology Act, 2000, but breaches still happen. It is crucial to use strong, unique passwords for all your online accounts and enable 2FA wherever possible. Be wary of saving your credit card details on websites, even if they claim to be secure. Instead, use tokenization if available or consider virtual credit cards for online shopping.

unnormalised: Overall, online transactions are reasonably safe if you take precautions. Be aware of the risks, follow security best practices, and stay vigilant against scams. Report any suspicious activity to your bank and the cybercrime cell. Remember to check your bank statements regularly for any unauthorized transactions. And perhaps most importantly, never share your OTP, CVV, or UPI PIN with anyone, no matter who they claim to be. Doing so can save you from potentially losing ₹ 50000, or even more.
